pros: Had some great shifts with great nurses, learned some new bandaging techniques, decent benefits/pay.  Made some friends.
cons: Manager wouldn't let me go back to school to get my paramedic certification, (the school didn't offer night classes for it either) I would have stayed longer had they let me do that.  Some nurses had no compassion for patients and didn't need to be in the field. Had one nurse say they were just in it for the money, could care less about patients.  Wasn't allowed to utilized my full EMT skill potential.  Work/life balance didn't fit my personal needs.

pros: I learn something new every single day. Whether it’s a cool new trick in LinkedIn or a new way to leverage our service, I am constantly learning. I get to use my skills and my ideas are valued, this provides a positive energy and of course feeling appreciated is wonderful! But the best part of working at MMH is working with amazing people. They’re smart, witty, ambitious and unbelievably caring. I have had a lot of really great (and some not so great) work environments in the past and the one I have going on now is such an interesting mix of personalities, interests and lifestyles. I strongly believe coworkers have the potential to influence pretty much every aspect of your work, sometimes for the better and sometimes for the worse. I can honestly say, mine are pretty great right now.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about my employer. They have been wonderful in my past 20+ years of employment.

pros: It's a beautiful remodeled facility. The cafeteria is really good. The insurance is not bad at all. Basic Hospital orientation was fun.
cons: The first day of hospital orientation the presenter told us that our name would be put into a raffle if we went on sites such as Glassdoor and gave them a 5 start review. This hospital is far from 5 stars. The CEO travels to other hospitals to see what they're doing and then brings their successful processes back to Midland Memorial. To be honest this hospital stripped the part time employees of their PTO. They changed their insurance and retirement benefits without telling anyone. People that worked there for decades that made the hospital wonderful are actually in the worst places in life right now because of them. It is a drama fest. The floor managers do not how to talk to you and are rude for no reason. Their CCU is a joke. They have patients in CCU with your everyday case of pneumonia because the doctors feel that medsurg nurses are too dumb to take care of them, seriously. It's the perfect making of a dark Medical comedy that would probably be cancelled in its first season and not given a chance have a finale.

job_title: Director of Inpatient Surgical Services in Midland, TX
pros: Midland Memorial is my second home!  The people here are fun and very friendly.  I like how process improvement is at the forefront of every agenda.  Nobody is satisfied with average.   The goal is always to be the best in everything.  For patient care, that means that evidence-based practices, quality care, & safety are priority.  Patient satisfaction is high because the nurses are very caring and they work hard to deliver high-quality care.  If you are looking for a great place to work, MMH is the place.  The hospital is beautiful which really helps the work atmosphere and efficiency.
cons: The EHR is in the process of getting updated.  Once the new system is in place, nursing documentation will not be as difficult for the nursing staff.   The current EHR is fully functioning and is not hard to learn---just time consuming.

pros: Positive working environment, happy coworkers and staff. Management has a proactive mindset when it comes to improving employee and patient moral. Management understands that the road for improvement is never ending, and they are looking for ways to consistently improve processes and procedures. Love the "Culture of Ownership" and the "Pickle Pledge." (see website for info)
cons: Benefits are set up on a high deductible plan, not co-pay.

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in Midland, TX
pros: Well-equipped, modernised hospital that makes one to feel proud to work there. Patient rooms are complete private rooms, with everything to make the patient feel at home. I will like to go back to work there if offered a new position commensurate to my academic status, and good pay structure. I love Midland Memorial Hospital.
cons: Lack of good pay, with exorbitant living conditions in the community.

pros: Can't think of any, it wasn't a good time in my career.
cons:
I was bullied for not being from the area, I was let go when I was diagnosed with breast cancer, I was treated poorly for having a lot of experience in many places from being an agency tech (they wanted everything done THEIR way-I even got yelled at for how I threw away CLEAN trash!)
I wanted to put ZERO stars as the overall rating, but it wouldn't let me. Anything on here with 1 star is supposed to be a zero!

job_title: Midland Health Employee in Midland, TX
pros:
Midland Memorial offers several programs that support your personal and professional goals, plus a variety of medical, dental and other benefit options that provide the coverage that best suits you. 
Midland Memorial Hospital offers a High Deductable Health Plan (HDHP) with a Health Savings Account (HSA) to help you cover a wide range of medical services. 
When you choose to enroll in the medical plan, you automatically have prescription drug coverage. Your prescription cost will go towards your deductable. Once your deductable has been met then you will have a coinsurance percentage that will apply per prescription order or refill.
Focusing on your health can pay off. Midland Memorial offers employees a wellness benefit each year which allows you to receive a discount on your premiums based off of your participation of the wellness program.
Memorial Hospital recognizes that healthy teeth and regular oral check-ups are an important part of your overall well-being. For this reason, we provide dental insurance that encourages preventive care and regular exams. Additionally, Midland Memorial’s dental plan allows you to visit any licensed dental provider in the United States.
After six months of employment, full-time and part-time employees are eligible for tuition assistance. Our assistance is 100 percent of approved courses completed with a grade of C or above, up to $3,000 a year for full-time employees and $1,500 for part-time employees. Midland Memorial also has a program through the Midland Memorial Foundation that will supplement our tuition assistance.
We also offer life insurance and accidental death and dismemberment insurance along with additional optional coverage for you and your family. We also offer long-term disability, flexible spending accounts for dependent day care; and voluntary short-term disability.The tobacco-free policy bans smoking and tobacco products at Midland Memorial Hospital inclusive of the hospital, the entire grounds, the outpatient pharmacy, West Campus, all the parking lots, hospital's off site locations, in hospital vehicles and in personal vehicles on hospital properties.
cons: one person’s cons may be another person’s pros

review_title: Over worked under paid and under appreciated
pros: Some other people I work with are amazing and have become life long friends. The facility for the most part is nice to work in when things aren't breaking or falling apart. Certain management actually work hard and fight for their nurses.
cons: NOT ENOUGH STAFF!! Possibly it's because we get paid less than any area hospital as full time staff. The only real way to make a living working less than 50+hours a week is to be a part of the recourse team because they make literally double if not two and a half times as much as a new hire full time employee. If the hospital would restrict how many resource nurses they were being allowed to hire then maybe the floors would be staffed with their own employees. The grass is not always green on the other side though. When a manager sees that a resource nurse is coming to the floor they will specifically give them a harder set of patients because "they get paid more to take he heavier patient loads". The clinical lader system is a joke... basically the only way to get a decent raise is to perform tasks for the hospital such as evidence based practice projects and earn a BSN instead of being based on performance or patient satisfaction. Most managers have no desire to help. They have little to no desire to actually help with patient care sometimes refusing to take a patient in order to keep a staff nurse from taking an unsafe patient load. Let's just say I've seen more nurses filing safe harbor in the last months than I ever would have imagined at such a large facility. This hospital has gone to hell in a hand basket in the last 2 years and everything they are trying to do to make it more cutting edge and "efficient" is making it harder and harder to actually work and care for patients which is the main reason most of us became nurses! As far as patient care goes... get ready to be treating a computer rather than your patients because the EHR system is difficult to navigate and is very redundant. I spend more time charting on my patients than I do actually caring for them... last and not least... it's saying something when you have most of the clinical managers on every floor stepping down or quitting even directors leaving and then their positions not being refilled... managers are jumping ship before  they go down with the boat. And a lot of employees are following suit...

review_title: MMH/MH.   CAPE- Education Coordinator Women's/Children's Services
job_title: Education Coordinator- Wonen's/Children's Services in Midland, TX
pros: THE Most Amazing place to work! Progressive, innovative, inspiring!!!  Fantastic growth opportunities in a family-atmosphere!  Patient- centric Professional Practice Model, flexible staffing options, and culture-shift align with personal, family, and career goals & values! West Texas Friendly atmosphere you will not find elsewhere!
cons: Life is short! Maximize your enjoyment! Find peace and supportive work-place in the time you are blessed with!!!  Everyday is truly a gift! Come share in ours!!

pros: Nice Facility- upgrading all the time, Good pay and benefits, High acuity so good place to learn, Versant residency program is really awesome and highly sought after from across the country.
cons: Political management, Some conflicts are pushed under the rug and not adequately dealt with. nurses "eat their young" (this is steadily improving), frequently understaffed.

pros: Challenging, freedom to make decisions independently, rewarding to work with patients, opportunities for creative thinking and program development.
cons: Chronically short-staffed due to economic issues in Midland, and the hospital has not taken adequate steps to keep up with the market, although I understand the dilemma of not being able to keep up salary-wise with oil companies, etc.  The management makes lots of promises, but at the end of the day, if your department's work is considered "good enough" you get very little support to make it better and fulfill it's full potential.

pros:
+ Self-scheduling 
+ Well paid if a resource nurse (but no benefits) 
+ New hospital with beautiful private rooms,
cons:
- Insufficient hourly wage for the cost of the area, 
- Lowest hourly wage compared to other health care facilities 
- Low pay for acuity compared to other health care facilities including rehab, clinics, and LTC
- Questionable salary compared to other industries
- High nurse to patient ratio 
- High staff turnover rates 
- Employee morale could be better
